choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis.

 

On a bone scan, a generalized increase in skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity. This is referred to as a super scan.

 

 

  • All the bones show diffusely increased uptake whereas kidneys are not visualized.
  • Seen with-
    1. Metabolic bone diseases
    2. Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased uptake by carcinoma prostate: While the primary prostate carcinoma may cause metastases, the increased uptake seen in a super scan specifically refers to bone metastases, not the primary tumor itself.

 

Option C. Increased uptake by the bone: This option is too general and does not specify the underlying cause, which in the context of a super scan is typically metastatic disease.

 

Option D. Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney: This choice misrepresents the scenario, as the decreased visualization of kidneys is a result of the intense skeletal uptake overshadowing other areas, not due to decreased uptake by these organs themselves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bone scan super scan appearance in a patient with known malignancy such as prostate cancer usually indicates extensive bone metastasis, necessitating aggressive management and treatment planning to address widespread disease.

questions.text: Identify the marked segment of liver. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V

 

Marked structure is Segment V of liver.

 

 

The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments based on the Couinaud classification system. Each segment has its own vascular and biliary supply.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver is divided into eight anatomical segments according to the Couinaud classification

questions.text: Most specific for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bilateral sacroiliitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Bilateral sacroilitis is a hallmark radiological feature of AS and is a key criterion in diagnostic classification.
  • Visible inflammation and structural changes in the sacroiliac joints, especially if bilateral, are highly indicative of AS.
  • This is considered a more specific diagnostic feature than HLA-B27 alone.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most initial symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
  • Radiographic features:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

  • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually, bony ankylosis.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen. 
  • Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B27. While HLA-B27 is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and is found in a large majority of patients, it's not the most specific for diagnosis on its own. The presence of HLA-B27 can be found in a significant percentage of the general population who do not have AS.

 

Option C. Lumbar movements. Lumbar movements are decreased in ankylosing spondylitis, but it is not specific to the disease.

 

Option D. ESR. ESR is a non-specific marker of inflammation. Increased ESR can be present in systemic infections, bone infections, rheumatic fever, tuberculosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is a significant genetic marker and helps in identifying individuals at risk, the most specific finding for diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis, particularly in its later stages, is often the presence of definite structural changes in the sacroiliac joints, especially bilateral sacroiliitis, on imaging.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain, where the red arrow points to the Cerebellum. This part of the brain is known for its role in motor control, and it can also be involved in some cognitive functions like attention and language.

 

Key features visible in the MRI that help identify the Cerebellum include its characteristic lobulated structure located at the posterior base of the brain, just below the cerebrum and behind the brainstem and fourth ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: Part of the brainstem, located higher and anteriorly relative to the cerebellum on sagittal images.

 

Option C. Brainstem: The brainstem, which includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla, is located anteriorly to the cerebellum in the image.

 

Option D. Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, covering most of the upper sections of the image, involved in various higher-order functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cerebellum, distinct in its appearance and location in the posterior aspect of the brain, plays crucial roles in the coordination of voluntary movements and motor functions, which can be clearly seen on sagittal MRI scans.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung Abscess

 

The image shows a cavity in the lung with an air-fluid level, which is characteristic of a lung abscess. A lung abscess typically appears as a localized collection of pus within the lung, caused by microbial infection, and is usually associated with an air-fluid level within a thick-walled cavity. This radiologic appearance is a hallmark of a lung abscess and distinguishes it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB (Tuberculosis): Tuberculosis can present with thick-walled cavities but typically does not show a distinct air-fluid level as seen in a lung abscess. TB lesions are often more irregular and do not exhibit the same characteristic air-fluid line.

 

Option C. Fungal Pneumonia: Fungal pneumonia often presents with multiple nodules and may display a "halo sign" (nodules surrounded by ground-glass opacity). It does not typically present as a single cavity with an air-fluid level.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition is characterized by the presence of both air and fluid in the pleural space, often leading to a visible air-fluid level, but the appearance is generally over a larger portion of the hemithorax and not within a lung cavity itself. It appears more diffuse rather than localized like a lung abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lung abscess is identified by a cavity with an air-fluid level on imaging, differentiating it from other pulmonary conditions like TB, fungal infections, and hydropneumothorax.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PET

 

The image provided shows a comparison between three types of imaging modalities: PET, CT, and PET-CT. PET (Positron Emission Tomography) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. In this case, the PET scan highlights areas of the body where the radioactive glucose analog 18F-FDG has been absorbed, typically areas with high glucose metabolism such as tumors.

 

The combined PET-CT image integrates the metabolic information from the PET scan with the anatomical detail provided by the CT scan, which allows for precise localization of the metabolic activity within the body's structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG: Ultrasound (USG) uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It does not produce the type of image shown in this question.

 

Option B. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures. The images from MRI are different from those of PET scans, which focus on metabolic activity.

 

Option D. X-ray: X-rays provide images based on the absorption of X-ray photons by different tissues, primarily used to visualize bone structures. The image shown is not an X-ray, as it does not display the typical bone-focused detail of X-ray imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation shown in the image is a PET scan (and PET-CT), which highlights areas of high metabolic activity, commonly used for detecting cancer.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kartagener syndrome

 

 

Kartagener syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia with situs inversus, is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of symptoms: bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus. The provided image shows clear evidence of situs inversus (with the heart apex and stomach bubble on the right side) and bronchiectasis (dilated bronchi seen on the X-ray). These findings align perfectly with Kartagener syndrome.

 

In this image:

 

  • The heart apex is seen on the right side, confirming dextrocardia.
  • The stomach bubble is also on the right side, indicating situs inversus.
  • There are multifocal dilated bronchi, which are signs of bronchiectasis.

 

These findings together strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labelling error: While it is crucial to confirm that the X-ray is correctly labeled (i.e., left and right markers), in this case, the labeling is correct, and the findings of situs inversus, dextrocardia, and bronchiectasis are genuine.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, which would not present as dextrocardia or bronchiectasis. It is not consistent with the X-ray findings shown.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis can also present with bronchiectasis, but it does not typically involve situs inversus or dextrocardia, making this an incorrect option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis, often identified by observing the positions of the heart, stomach bubble, and bronchi on imaging.

questions.text: An 88-year-old male presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain. On physical examination, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115 bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72 mm of Hg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding.
  • Most sensitive X-ray: CXR-PA erect.
  • Most sensitive Ix: CECT with oral contrast.
  • Next step: Resuscitation with IV fluids, Exploratory laparotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: Involves air in the pleural space, not under the diaphragm. The clinical presentation and X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized pain and fever, but X-ray findings would be more consistent with an abscess formation rather than free air.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While it might present with abdominal pain and distension, free air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic finding unless there is a concurrent bowel perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumoperitoneum is a critical finding indicating a potential perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, requiring immediate assessment and surgical intervention. This diagnosis is supported by the presence of free air under the diaphragm seen on the X-ray.

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: de-Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves tendon sheath of which two muscles? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic. The examiner places patient’s thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction. In positive test this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the opposite thumb is relatively painless.

 

 

Finkelstein’s test – de Quervain’s tenosynovitis

 

  • Differential diagnosis: 
    • Scaphoid non-union
    • Arthritis at the base of thumb
    • Intersection syndrome
       
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is the inflammation of the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

Imaging

 

  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

Treatment:

 

Drugs used in osteoporosis are:

 

  1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
  2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
  3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis: Incorrect, as spondylolysis refers to a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebrae, not typically associated with the changes seen in the X-ray provided.

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis: Incorrect, this condition involves the forward slippage of one vertebra over the one beneath it, which would show distinct alignment changes not described in the X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Incorrect, as osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by the abnormal density and sclerosis of bone, quite the opposite of what is observed in osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoporosis is a condition marked by a decrease in bone density and mass, leading to structural weakening of the bone and increased risk of fractures. Diagnostic imaging such as X-rays can show characteristic changes like "Codfish Vertebra" and is further confirmed by measuring bone mineral density through a DEXA scan. Treatment focuses on inhibiting bone resorption and/or stimulating bone formation through various pharmacological agents.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has appreciable shortening in her right leg. She is diagnosed with TB Hip. Her presentation will come under which stage? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage III

 

STAGES OF TUBERCULOSIS OF HIP

 

  • Stage 1: 
    • Stage of synovitis
    • FABER (Flexion, Abduction and External rotation)
    • Lengthening
  • Stage 2: 
    • Stage of early arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • <1 cm shortening
  • Stage 3: 
    • Stage of advanced arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • >1 cm shortening
    • Appreciable shortening is a key characteristic.
  • Stage 4: 
    • Stage of subluxation/dislocation
    • Wandering acetabulum or pestle and mortar appearance
  • Stage 5: 
    • Stage of sequelae, ankylosis or severe arthritis

 

 

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

 

 

Additionally,

  • Stage V: Described as a "fused, finished off joint" known as fibrous ankylosis. This stage represents the end progression of certain joint diseases where there is complete fusion of the joint surfaces.
  • In TB affecting peripheral joints, such as the hip and knee, the fusion is more commonly fibrous ankylosis, where the fusion involves more fibrous tissue rather than direct bone fusion. This is painful condition. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I:

  • Known as the stage of synovitis.
  • Characterized by increased capacity of the hip.
  • The position of comfort is FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation).
  • FABER leads to lengthening of the leg, not shortening.

 

Option B. Stage II:

  • Early arthritis stage with joint damage.
  • The lower limb adopts a position of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.
  • Shortening is present but is > 1 cm and not appreciable.

 

Option D. Stage IV:

  • Involves destruction of the bone and changes in the shape of the joint.
  • The femoral head migrates, causing subluxation or dislocation.
  • Known as the stage of the wandering acetabulum, a misnomer for the wandering femoral head.
  • Not specifically associated with the appreciable shortening described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Stage III of TB hip is characterized by late or advanced arthritis with appreciable shortening of the leg (> 1 cm).

questions.text: Which drug is used as a first line management for postmenopausal female with osteoporosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases (pyrophosphate analogs) bind to the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals and inhibits resorption.
  • These drugs are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine.
  • Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss (as occurs with estrogen replacement therapy).
  • These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non-vertebral fractures.
  • These are the drugs of choice in postmenopausal osteoporotic females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raloxifene. Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) act as estrogen antagonist in breast tissue and as an agonist in bone. Raloxifene selectively stimulates estrogen receptor in bone and is used in treatment of osteoporosis. It reduces risk of breast cancer also.

 

Option C. Estrogen. Hormone replacement therapy is the mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis with estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Combined OC pills. Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) alleviate climacteric symptoms and might have a positive effect on BMD. Of note, progestin is the dominant component over estrogen in COCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first line drugs or drugs of choice to treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma center after RTA with shortness of breath. The supine CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemothorax

 

The provided supine chest X-ray (CXR) shows a generalized opacity throughout the left hemithorax, which is characteristic of a hemothorax. In a trauma setting, chest X-rays are often taken in the supine position because the patient cannot stand. In this position, the fluid from a hemothorax gravitates and spreads out across the thoracic cavity, leading to a uniform opacity on the affected side.

 

Hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, often occurs due to trauma and presents with symptoms of shortness of breath. The key radiographic feature on a supine CXR is the diffuse opacity without a typical meniscus sign, which is seen in erect chest X-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: This condition presents with hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) in the affected hemithorax. In a supine CXR, a deep sulcus sign might be seen, but there is no hyperlucency present in the image, ruling out pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Pulmonary contusion: Pulmonary contusions appear as localized areas of consolidation. They do not typically cause uniform opacity throughout an entire hemithorax as seen in this image.

 

Option D. Diaphragm injury: Diaphragm injuries can result in the presence of bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a supine chest X-ray of a trauma patient, a hemothorax presents as a diffuse opacity throughout the affected hemithorax due to the gravitational spread of blood in the pleural space.

choices.text: Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv
CT is the initial investigation for gallstones

questions.text: Identify the correct statement: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HU of water is zero

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) is a measure of radiodensity used in computed tomography (CT) scanning. By definition, the HU of water is zero, and this value serves as the reference point for measuring the density of other tissues. Values greater than zero indicate substances denser than water (e.g., bone, contrast material), while values less than zero indicate less dense substances (e.g., fat, air).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT uses non-filtered X-rays: This statement is incorrect. CT scans use filtered X-rays to remove low-energy X-rays that would not contribute to image formation but would increase patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv: This is incorrect. Typical radiation doses for CT scans vary based on the body part being imaged. A head CT scan, for instance, typically involves a radiation dose of around 2 mSv, while an abdominal CT scan might be around 5 mSv. A dose of 20 mSv would be exceedingly high for a single CT scan.

 

Option C. CT is the initial investigation for gallstones: This is incorrect. Ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice for gallstones due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and lack of ionizing radiation. CT is more commonly used for other types of stones, such as kidney stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) of water is zero, serving as a reference point for measuring the radiodensity of various tissues in CT imaging.

questions.text: Rickets occurs due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D

 

  • Rickets is a skeletal disorder that results from a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. 
  • The primary cause of rickets is a lack of Vitamin D, which is essential for the absorption of calcium and phosphate in the body. 
  • Without adequate Vitamin D, bones can become soft and weak.
  • Key features of rickets include:
    • Cupping: The metaphyseal ends of bones become cup-shaped.
    • Splaying: An increase in the width of the metaphyseal ends.
    • Flaring: The ends of the bones point outward.

 

 

  • These characteristics are critical diagnostic features of rickets and help differentiate it from other bone disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to issues like night blindness and impaired immunity.

 

Option B. Vitamin B: B vitamins are crucial for energy production and neurological function. 

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums and joint pain. In vitamin C deficiency, the bony ends appear more white on radiographs (Whitening).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rickets is primarily caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, which leads to characteristic bone deformities such as cupping, splaying, and flaring of the metaphyseal ends.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jejunal atresia

 

The image provided shows the classic "triple bubble" sign, which is characteristic of jejunal atresia. In this condition, there are three distinct bubbles visible on the radiograph: the stomach, the proximal duodenum, and the distal duodenum. This occurs because the blockage is located at the level of the jejunum, causing dilatation of the preceding segments of the intestine.

 

Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where a portion of the jejunum is absent or closed, leading to obstruction. This results in the accumulation of air and fluid in the segments of the intestine proximal to the obstruction, creating the appearance of multiple bubbles on imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small bowel obstruction: Typically presents with multiple air-fluid levels throughout the bowel, rather than the distinct "bubble" signs seen in jejunal atresia.

 

Option C. Duodenal atresia: Characterized by the "double bubble" sign, where only two bubbles are visible: one in the stomach and one in the proximal duodenum. The third bubble seen in the image rules out duodenal atresia.

 

Option D. CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis): Presents with a single bubble on the radiograph, representing a dilated stomach. The pyloric stenosis prevents stomach contents from passing into the duodenum, leading to a single dilated stomach bubble.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "triple bubble" sign is indicative of jejunal atresia, where three dilated segments are visible on the radiograph: the stomach, proximal duodenum, and distal duodenum. This sign is crucial for differentiating jejunal atresia from other types of intestinal obstructions like duodenal atresia or small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Which injury is not a part of ‘terrible triad of elbow’? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture of olecranon

 

TERRIBLE TRIAD OF ELBOW

 

  • A notoriously unstable injury is the elbow dislocation with associated fractures of the radial head and coronoid process of the ulna is termed the terrible triad of the elbow.
  • Elbow dislocation is often associated with posterolateral dislocation or LCL injury.
  • Mechanism of injury is fall on supinated forearm and extended arm that results in a combination of valgus, axial, and posterolateral rotatory forces.
  • This produces posterolateral dislocation.
  • Structures of elbow fail from lateral to medial:  
    • LCL
    • Anterior capsule
    • Possible MCL disruption
  • Patients complain of pain, clicking and locking with elbow in extension.
  • Physical examination shows possible varus / valgus instability patterns.
  • Radiographs help evaluate the concentricity of humeroulnar and radiocapitellar joints; specifically, lateral films can assist in diagnosing coronoid fractures.

 

 

  • CT scan is routinely obtained to identify fracture patterns, comminution, and displacement, which may not be evident on plain radiographs. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fracture of olecranon is not a part of the terrible triad injury of the elbow.
  • In the terrible triad injury, the radial head and coronoid process are fractured, along with dislocation of the elbow joint.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the Flexor Carpi Radialis.
  • The flexor carpi radialis muscle is a long, superficial muscle of the forearm that belongs to the anterior muscle group and lies in the first layer.
  • It is a relatively thin muscle located on the anterior part of the forearm.
  • It arises in the humerus epicondyle, close to the wrist area.
  • It is a superficial muscle that becomes very visible as the wrist comes into flexion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Flexor Carpi Ulnaris: The flexor carpi ulnaris can be palpated by locating the bony landmarks associated to the muscle including the medial epicondyle, the olecranon process and the pisiform bone. After identifying the bony landmarks, the person is asked to perform ulnar deviation and wrist flexion simultaneously, which will help locate the FCU muscle.

 

 

Option. C. Palmaris Longus: The Palmaris longus (PL) muscle is a long, slender muscle which is usually present in the superficial volar compartment of the forearm, interposed between the Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and the Flexor Carpi Radialis muscles. This muscle is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

 

Option. D. Extensor Carpi Radialis: Extensor carpi radialis is a muscle that can be found in the posterior compartment of the forearm. It is partly overlapped by brachioradialis and these muscles often blend together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The marked muscle tendon in the image is of the flexor carpi radialis muscle.

questions.text: Which contrast is used in PET scan? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FDG

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is an imaging technique used primarily in oncology, cardiology, and neurology. The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose). FDG (a ligand) is a radiopharmaceutical composed of glucose molecules labeled with the positron-emitting isotope fluorine-18.

 

When injected into the body, FDG mimics glucose and is taken up by cells with high glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells. The Warburg effect, a phenomenon where cancer cells preferentially consume glucose for energy, makes FDG particularly useful in identifying tumors. The positrons emitted by fluorine-18 interact with electrons in the body, producing gamma rays that are detected by the PET scanner to create detailed images of metabolic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iohexol: Iohexol is an iodinated contrast agent typically used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans, not PET scans. It does not emit positrons and is not used to highlight areas of high metabolic activity.

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is not used as a contrast agent in PET scans. While calcium can be a component of certain contrast agents used in other types of imaging like fluoroscopy, it has no role in PET imaging.

 

Option C. Gadolinium: Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). It helps enhance the contrast of images in MRI but does not work with the PET scanning process, which relies on positron emission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), which highlights areas of increased glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

 

  • The images show the cervical vertebrae where, at the lower cervical spine (C4-C7), there is an anterior slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. 
  • In the left image, C5 appears to be shifted anteriorly relative to C6. 
  • This slippage is referred to as spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis involves forward displacement of one vertebra over another.
  • Pathology:
    • The pars interarticularis is disrupted on both sides (spondylolysis), separating the posterior neural arch from vertebral body; gap is later filled by fibrous tissue.
    • The vertebral body undergoes anterior dislocation under stress.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Lateral view: Forward shift of the upper part of spinal column on the stable vertebra below; elongation of the arch or defective facets may be seen.
    • Oblique views are needed to clearly demonstrate fracture of pars interarticularis (Beheaded Scottie dog sign)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a systemic condition characterized by reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), and codfish appearance. It typically appears as generalized radiolucency (bones look "thinner" or "washed out") and potentially vertebral compression fractures. 

 

 

Option C. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect or fracture at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. It is difficult to definitively diagnose spondylolysis on a plain lateral cervical X-ray without oblique views or a CT.  

 

 

Option D. Discitis. This is an or infection of the intervertebral disc and adjacent vertebral bodies. Radiographically, it would typically show disc space narrowing. This is not the primary finding observed in these images. Discitis is a serious but uncommon infection or inflammation of the intervertebral disc space. Radiographic findings include the narrowing of disc space, irregular endplates, and sometimes erosions or sclerosis of the vertebral bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the given question shows spondylolisthesis of C6 vertebra over C7 vertebra.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with sudden severe headache. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage)

 

The CT scan shows hyperdensity (bright white areas) within the CSF cisterns, indicating the presence of blood. This presentation is typical of a Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH), which is often caused by a ruptured aneurysm, particularly in the circle of Willis, as confirmed by the accompanying CT angiography. The sudden severe headache experienced by the patient, often described as a "thunderclap headache," is characteristic of SAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SDH (Subdural Hemorrhage): SDH typically appears as a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid membrane. It is not confined to the CSF cisterns and does not present with the sudden onset severe headache seen in SAH.

 

Option C. EDH (Epidural Hemorrhage): EDH is characterized by a biconvex, lens-shaped appearance on imaging. It is usually associated with trauma and does not involve the subarachnoid space or present with CSF cistern hyperdensity.

 

Option D. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, often due to trauma or surgical procedures. It shows air density areas on imaging, which appear black, unlike the hyperdense (white) blood seen in SAH. The classic sign associated with pneumocephalus is the Mount Fuji sign, which is not seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAH presents with sudden, severe headache and is identified on CT by hyperdensity in the CSF cisterns. The most common cause is aneurysmal rupture, best evaluated using CT angiography.

questions.text: Which part of 2nd metatarsal is involved in the march fracture?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck

 

MARCH FRACTURE

 

  • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck.
  • The second metatarsal is more prone to injury due to its limited motion from strong ligamentous attachment to the first and second cuneiforms and length compared to the other foot metatarsals.
  • They result from a sudden increase in the intensity, duration, and frequency of activity without sufficient rest.
  • The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes microfractures, which consolidate into stress fractures and are not the result of a single traumatic event.

 

 

  • Common Fracture Eponyms:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The march fracture involves the neck of the 2nd metatarsal followed by 3rd metatarsal.
  • It is a stress fracture of the metatarsal.

questions.text: Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prepatellar bursa

 

PREPATELLAR BURSA

 

  • Prepatellar bursitis or inflammation of the prepaterllar bursa is called Housemaid’s knee.
  • There is swelling in the front of the knee joint.
  • Prepatellar bursa is a small fluid-filled sac in front of the patella. It provides cushioning and protection.
  • Too much pressure on the bursa produces more fluid to protect the knee. This causes build up of swelling in the knee.
  • Prepatellar bursitis is usually caused by repetitive kneeling (common knee position in housemaids for cleaning hence, named as housemaid’s knee) or sudden blow to the front of the knee due to fall.

 

 

  • It is seen more often in men than women.
  • 80% patients are of age 40-60m years.
  • 1/3rd of prepatellar bursitis are septic and 2/3rd are aseptic.
  • Infectious bursitis emerges more often in children than adults.
  • The bursitis settles down within few weeks by conservative treatment. It rarely require any surgical intervention.
  • Etiology:
    • Repetitive kneeling
    • Sudden force or blow or fall on front of knee
    • Constant friction between skin and patella
    • Coexisting inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or gout
    • Ocassionally, due to a bacterial infection (S.aureus in 80% cases)
  • Clinical features:
    • Swelling in front of the knee
    • Knee pain particularly on moving the knee
    • Difficulty in bending the knee, kneel down, or walk
    • Slight redness, differential warmth, and tenderness over the affected area

 

 

  • If present with infection, pain is associated with fever and chills
     
  • Diagnosis is made through detailed history of onset of symptoms, pattern of pain and effect on lifestyle, and physical examination.
  • It does not require X-ray or MRI or CT scan. They can be done to rule out any fracture or soft tissue injury.
  • If uncertain of infection of bursa, arthrocentesis can be done.
  • Treatment:
    • PRICE regimen in initial 72 hours after the injury or when the first sign of inflammation appears, to reduce pain and swelling
    • NSAIDs, topical medications
    • Stretching exercises
    • If swelling is increased, fluid aspiration with needle is done
    • Cortisone injection into the bursa
    • Antibiotic treatment if cause is an infection
    • Arthroscopic bursectomy or excision of bursa, if all treatment methods fail

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapatellar bursa. Suprapatellar bursitis causes pain and swelling just above the knee joint. It is also called as quadriceps tendon bursitis. It may be caused from repetitive overuse in sports, frequent kneeling, injury, coexisting medical condition, or tightness in the quadriceps muscle.

 

 

Option C. Infrapatellar bursa. Also called as Clergyman’s knee, infrapatellar bursitis causes pain just below the patella. It can be caused from frequent kneeling or crawling; overuse activities like running, jumping, kicking, climbing stairs; injury to the knee; secondary to patellar tendonitis and Osgood Schlatters disease; infection.

 

 

Option D. Pes anserine bursa. Pes anserine bursitis, also called intertendinous bursa, is the inflammation of the bursa of the conjoined insertion of Sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus (Pes anserinus). The pain due to this bursitis occurs on the inside of the knee, mostly during running or climbing up the stairs. There may be a spontaneous anteromedial knee pain on walking up or down the stairs. There is swelling and tenderness around the affected bursa; decreased ROM also.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Housemaid’s knee is caused by the inflammation in the prepatellar bursa. It causes pain in the front of the knee.
  • Inflammation in other bursa of the knee causes pain above, below or anteromedial to the knee.

questions.text: Glucosamine supplementation is given in:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arthritis

 

TREATMENT OF OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Maintain movement and muscle strength by physiotherapy and graded muscle exercise.
  • Protects the joint from overload by giving rest and weight reduction.
  • Correction of deformities if present.
  • Thermal modalities, analgesic medication, wedged insoles, orthosis and arthroscopic debridement and lavage.
  • Progressive joint destruction require joint replacement in elderly and HTO in young.
  • Stages of osteoarthritis:

 

 

  • Classification system and stage-wise management for osteoarthritis (OA) knee:
    • Initial treatment is always conservative (exercise and glucosamine are preferred).
    • Clinical picture is more significant than radiology or X-ray changes.
    • If activities of daily living are affected, surgery is advised.
    • Surgery for young patients is high tibial osteotomy (HTO) (if not contraindicated), if contraindicated, total knee replacement (TKR) is performed.
    • Surgery for elderly (> 65 years) is TKR.
    • Usually for stage 2 onwards in elderly, TKR is finally carried out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucosamine supplementations are given in the treatment of osteoarthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be used for new bone formation in cases of non-union fracture?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic protein

 

PROPERTIES OF GRAFT MATERIALS

 

 

 

  • Atrophic non union (absent callus, poor bone biology, lack of blood supply) are fixed by internal fixation with biologic stimulation.
  • Biologic stimulation is done with bone graft and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP).
  • Although the gold standard in nonunion therapy is the transplantation of autologous bone graft, missing bone regeneration subsequent to transplantation of autologous bone graft poses a serious disadvantage for the patients. Therefore, in the last few years, this therapy was combined with the application of bone morphogenetic protein-7 (BMP-7).
  • Use of BMP-7 is approved for tibial non-unions.
  • BMP-2 is approved for 1 level degenerative disk disease in spinal fusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate. Calcium Phosphate Cement is a useful bone substitute for benign bone tumor surgery. It provides excellent osteoconductivity and long-lasting stability without internal fixation.

 

Option B. Caclium sulphate. Calcium sulfate is a synthetic ceramic bone graft substitutes which has an osteoconductive property. It is a bio-inert material which gets resorbed over a period of weeks and fibrovascular tissue takes its place which eventually allows neovascularisation and bone formation within the area. Use of calcium sulfate as a bone graft substitutes avoids the complications and morbidity associated with autograft like infection.

 

Option C. PMMA. Polymethylmethacrylate is one of the most enduring materials in orthopaedic surgery. It has a central role in the success of total joint replacement and is also used in newer techniques such as percutaneous vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BMP helps in bone formation and repair. Thus, for the union of non-united fractures by surgery, it is used as an autograft material.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Correctly identified based on the image, this stricture is located in the bulbar region of the urethra, just below the prostate and above the penile segment.

 

This is a urethrogram, a type of radiographic study used to evaluate the urethra. The narrowing seen in the image is consistent with a bulbar urethral stricture, which typically occurs in the part of the urethra that runs through the bulb of the penis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prostatomegaly: This would show an enlarged prostate, which typically does not affect the urethra directly on a urethrogram unless there is significant compression or involvement of the prostatic urethra.

 

Option B. Membranous urethral stricture: This type of stricture would occur in the membranous segment of the urethra, which is located between the prostate and the bulbous urethra. The location in this image does not correspond to that segment.

 

Option D. Normal urethra: This would show an unobstructed and uniformly calibred urethral passage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Urethral strictures, particularly in the bulbar region, are commonly evaluated and diagnosed with a urethrogram, which provides clear visualization of any narrowing or obstruction along the urethral tract.

choices.text: Conservative management is the mainstay therapy
Posture of finger is in extension
Pain on passive extension of finger

questions.text: True about acute tenosynovitis is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive extension of finger

 

ACUTE SUPPURATIVE TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • It is purulent infection of synovial flexor sheath.
  • It may be the result of the spread of adjacent pulp infections or puncture wounds in the flexor creases.

 

 

  • Although the flexor sheath is usually involved, the radial and ulnar bursae may be involved as well.
  • Most common organism – Staphylococcus aureus
  • Most common digits involved – Ring, middle and index fingers
  • Kanavel’s sign:
    • Rigid positioning of finger in flexion
    • Tenderness over tendon sheath (most significant)
    • Severe pain on passive extension of involved digit
    • Fusiform swelling of involved digit

 

 

  • Treatment
    • Immediate treatment with antibiotics and splinting may abort spread of the infection, if symptoms present for less than 48 hours.
    • Established pyogenic tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency – prompt surgical drainage along with antibiotics.
    • If drainage is required, an open or closed irrigation technique can be used.
    • If an open technique is used, healing and rehabilitation are prolonged, and full motion may not be regained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management is the mainstay therapy. This statement is false. They gold standard treatment is irrigation and debridement of the flexor sheath.

 

Option B. More commonly involves thumb. This is statement is incorrect. The index, middle and ring fingers are more commonly involved.

 

Option C. Posture of finger is in extension. This statement is incorrect. The affected finger remains in flexion. There is pain on active or passive extension of the finger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute suppurative tenosynovitis of the finger is a purulent infection of the flexor tendon sheath of the finger.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

 

MR spectroscopy is the next best step when multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed in the basal parts of the brain, suggesting tuberculomas. MR spectroscopy helps differentiate tuberculomas from other similar conditions, like neurocysticercosis (NCC), by identifying a characteristic lipid-lactate peak. The presence of this peak strongly favors a diagnosis of tuberculosis rather than NCC, which typically does not show this peak. This approach is a non-invasive and specific method to further evaluate the lesions, aligning with standard clinical protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is mainly used for confirming tuberculous meningitis rather than localized brain lesions such as tuberculomas. It is not useful in directly evaluating ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI.

 

Option C. Biopsy: Biopsy is an invasive procedure and is usually not the first choice due to potential complications. It is reserved for cases where non-invasive methods fail to provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. SWI (Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging): SWI is used primarily for detecting bleeds, microhemorrhages, or diffuse axonal injuries. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions caused by infections like tuberculosis or neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease comprised of four components:

 

  1. Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart
  2. Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure
  3. Overriding of aorta
  4. Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia

 

If ASD plus – pentalogy of Fallot

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: Typically presents with an enlarged and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is not specifically indicated by the features in this X-ray.

 

Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Generally shows a characteristic "egg on a string" sign on chest X-ray, which is not evident in this image.

 

Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Would show features like a "snowman" or "figure of 8" heart due to dilatation of the supra-cardiac veins, which is not visible here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a distinctive boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, correlating with the anatomical components of this congenital heart defect, making it a key diagnostic feature in cyanotic pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a mass in the right kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma        

 

Explanation:

 

The case of an elderly man with a heterogeneous large renal mass in the CECT image suggests renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC often appears as a solid renal mass with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage that cause the heterogeneity in density seen on CT images. This type of cancer is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and can present with various imaging appearances, but a large, irregular, and heterogeneous mass is highly suggestive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma: Typically appears as a well-circumscribed mass with a significant fat component, which should show negative Hounsfield units (HU) on CT, which is not evident in the presented image.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Generally presents as a well-circumscribed, homogenous mass with a central scar. It does not typically appear as heterogeneous as RCC.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure with very well-defined borders and no solid components, which does not match the characteristics of the mass show

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the image shown below?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxa vara

 

  • Coxa vara is a term used to describe a reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.
  • It may be congenital/acquired (growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis) or acquired (secondary to various other pathologies).
  • The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara.

 

 

  • This is coxa vara resulting from some unknown growth anomaly at the upper femoral epiphysis.
  • It is noticed as a painless limp in a child who has just started walking.
  • In severe cases, shortening of the leg may be obvious.
  • On examination, abduction and internal rotation of the hip are limited and the leg is short.
  • X-rays will show a reduction in neck-shaft angle.
  • The epiphyseal plate may be too vertical.
  • There may be a separate triangle of bone in the inferior portion of the metaphysis, called Fairbank’s triangle.

 

 

  • Treatment: Subtrochanteric corrective osteotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxa magna. Coxa magna is the asymmetrical, circumferential enlargement and deformation of the femoral head and neck. It is seen in Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, transient synovitis of the hip, developmental dysplasia of the hip, trauma, septic arthritis/osteomyelitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

 

 

Option B. Coxa valga. Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow acetabular angles and femoral head subluxation. Bilateral coxa valga can be seen in cerebral palsy, turner syndrome. Unilateral occurs due to trauma causing growth plate arrest. Angle more than 140° is considered as coxa valga.

 

 

 

Option D. Coxa Saltans. It is a condition characterized by a snapping sensation in the hip that comprises of 3 entities: external snapping hip (caused by iliotibial tract sliding over greater trochanter), internal snapping hip (caused by iliopsoas tendon sliding over femoral head, iliopectineal ridge, lesser trochanter, and iliopsoas bursa), and intra-articular snapping hip (caused by loose body in hip/labral tears). It is common in athletes and dancers in their teens or twenties. X-ray usually appears normal. MRI may show inflamed bursa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows coxa vara i.e., reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.

questions.text: External beam radiotherapy uses: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Co60

 

External beam radiotherapy, a cornerstone in the treatment of various cancers, utilizes high-energy beams to target and destroy cancer cells.

 

Co60 is a common radioisotope used in external beam radiotherapy due to its high-energy gamma rays, which are effective at penetrating tissues to treat tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobalt-59 (Co59): Co59 is not used in radiation therapy; it is a stable isotope of cobalt.

 

Option C. Strontium: Strontium isotopes (like Sr-89) are used in the treatment of bone metastases, not typically in external beam radiotherapy. They help alleviate pain by targeting cancerous cells in the bone.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus (typically P-32) is used in radiopharmaceuticals for treating specific types of blood disorders and polycythemia vera, not in external beam radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBRT uses Cobalt 60 as the radioisotope.

questions.text: Identify the marked rib. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4th Posterior

 

Marked rib is 4th posterior.

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior ribs on a chest X-ray are horizontally oriented, while anterior ribs are obliquely oriented.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: (AIIMS Nov 2019)

 

  1. More common in males than females.
  2. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  3. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur.
  4. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

 

Explanation:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Etiology:
    • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. 
    • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
    • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • Treatment:

 

 

  • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

questions.text: The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G2 phase

 

Each phase of the cell cycle exhibits different levels of sensitivity to radiation damage:

 

This is the second gap phase after DNA synthesis where the cell prepares for mitosis. Cells in the G2 phase are more sensitive to radiation than those in the G1 and S phases, as the cell checks for DNA damage and repairs it before proceeding to mitosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where the cell divides into two daughter cells.. The cell's machinery is entirely focused on the mitotic process, making it less able to repair DNA damage effectively.

 

Option C. S Phase: During this phase, DNA replication occurs. Cells are more resistant to radiation in the S phase because the DNA is actively being synthesized, and the repair processes are robust.

 

Option D. G1 Phase: This is the first gap phase, where cells increase in size and prepare the necessary components for DNA synthesis. Cells in the G1 phase are relatively resistant to radiation compared to other phases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-> M  (G2>M) phase. During this phase cells are particularly vulnerable to radiation because any damage caused during this phase can lead to immediate catastrophic errors in cell division, leading to cell death.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following presentation as shown in the image. Physical examination shows high riding medially rotated scapula, shaped like an equilateral triangle. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klippel-Feil deformity

 

KLIPPEL-FEIL SYNDROME

 

  • Klippel-Feil Syndrome is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae.
  • It presents with a classical triad of low hair line, short ‘web' neck (prominence of trapezius muscle), and limited neck motion seen in 50% cases.

 

 

  • Abnormal head position, true torticollis, and restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture is an indication for X-rays of cervical spine for evidence of cervical fusion.
  • It is associated with congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine, involving two or more vertebrae. Such fusions can involve the craniocervical junction (occiput to C2), the subaxial cervical spine or both; and results from a failure of the normal division of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis.

 

Associated Features:

  • Scoliosis (~60%) due to fusion of cervical and cervicothoracic junction.
  • Sprengel's deformity (~50%): it is congenitally elevated or undescended scapula (Omovertebral bone bridges the cervical spine to the scapula and limits the neck and shoulder motion)
  • Webbing of neck, facial asymmetry and torticollis.
  • Radiographic findings of congenital cervical vertebral fusion are diagnostic.
  • Neurological sequelae due to involvement of brain stem or cervical cord may be present.
  • Syndactyly and diffuse or focal upper extremity hypoplasia.
  • Secondary osteoarthritis, disc degeneration, spinal stenosis.
  • Genito-renal anomalies (~35%, so USG is recommended)
  • Congenital heart defects (~15%, so ECHO is recommended)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sprengel’s deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Option B. Separated shoulder deformity. A shoulder separation is not truly an injury to the shoulder joint. The injury actually involves the acromioclavicular joint. The most common cause for a separation of the AC joint is from a fall directly onto the shoulder, injuring the ligaments around the AC joint. If the force is severe enough, the ligaments attaching to the underside of the clavicle are torn, causing the separation of the clavivle and the scapula. The scapula moves downward from the weight of the arm, creating a bump or bulge above the shoulder.

 

 

Option C. Torticollis. Torticollis is a symptom of cervical spine abnormality. Congenital torticollis is due to fibrosis of sternocleidomastoid muscle on one side that fails to elongate as child grows. The cause is muscle ischemia from a distorted position in utero (breech) or birth injury. A history of difficult labour followed by lump over SCM (sternomastoid tumor) in first few weeks of life, which disappears in few months is present. Then, there is neither deformity nor obvious limitation of movements. Deformity does not become apparent until the child is 1-2 years old. SCM on involved side may feel tight and hard and a mass or knot can be detected in the body of SCM. It can disappear spontaneously. There may be asymmetrical development of face (plagiocephaly).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High riding medially rotated scapula, shaped like an equilateral triangle is seen in Klippel-Feil syndrome. This occurs due to congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae in the craniocervical junction and/or subaxial cervical spine.

questions.text: PET scan is based on: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose metabolism

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans are primarily based on glucose metabolism. The radiopharmaceutical used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), which is an analog of glucose. This radiotracer is preferentially taken up by cells that have a high rate of glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells. The Warburg effect explains this phenomenon, where cancer cells consume glucose at much higher rates than normal cells, making them visible on PET scans due to the concentration of 18F-FDG.

 

Once 18F-FDG is inside the cell, it undergoes phosphorylation but does not proceed through the full glycolytic pathway, leading to its trapping within the cell. The emitted positrons from fluorine-18 collide with electrons in the body, producing gamma rays, which are detected by the PET scanner to create an image showing areas of high glucose metabolism.

 

Other 3 Options are incorrect, not the basis for PET scan.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

PET scans are based on glucose metabolism, utilizing 18F-FDG to detect areas of high metabolic activity, particularly in cancer cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is a water soluble contrast? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iohexol

 

Explanation:

 

lohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium, used in various radiographic studies including CT scans, angiography, and myelography. It is known for its low osmolality and good safety profile, making it suitable for intravascular use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium: While barium sulfate is a contrast agent, it is not water-soluble and is primarily used for gastrointestinal studies.

 

Option C. Bromium: Not typically used as a contrast agent in medical imaging.

 

Option D. Calcium: Not used as a contrast agent. In medical imaging, calcium deposits may be identified by their radiographic appearance, but calcium itself is not administered as a contrast medium.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S phase

 

Explanation:

 

S phase of the cell cycle is considered the most radioresistant. During the S phase, cells are actively duplicating their DNA. The replication machinery during this phase makes the DNA less accessible to radiation-induced damage and the cell has enhanced mechanisms to repair any damage that does occur, thereby making it more resistant to the effects of radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M phase: The mitotic phase where cells are actively dividing. This phase and G2 are often considered more radiosensitive because cells are highly vulnerable to damage during mitosis.

 

Option C. G1 phase: The first gap phase where cells grow and prepare to synthesize DNA. This phase is relatively more radiosensitive compared to the S phase.

 

Option D. G2 phase: The second gap phase right before mitosis where cells prepare to divide. This phase is typically more radiosensitive, as cells are preparing for mitosis and have less capability for DNA repair compared to the S phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: In spine straightening surgeries, screws used for fixation are inserted through which of the following parts of the vertebra? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pedicle

 

  • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added. 

  • In the spine straightening surgery, to stabilize the spine, screws are placed on the pedicles of the vertebral bone. 

 

 

  • Hooks may also be used in conjunction with screws, and are placed around the pedicle or around the lamina.

  • Rods are then secured in the screw heads, connecting adjacent vertebrae. 

  • The rods are shaped to match the desired corrected curvature of the spine, and are attached to the screws and/or hooks.

  • Bone graft material is placed around the final assembly and as the spine heals, spinal fusion is accomplished by bone growth between the vertebrae. This bone growth permanently fixes the spine in the desired position. The implants hold the spine in the corrected position while the spine fuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

questions.text: Which of the following condition will cause intermittent breaking of long bones in a child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood.
  • It is also known as Lobstein-Vrolik brittle bone disease.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline sharply after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal (climacteric) women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
    • Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer.
    • Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve
    • Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected.
    • Skin becomes thin and translucent. Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
    • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
       
  • Prenatal diagnosis: Abnormal Pro a chain
  • Radiological features:
    • Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. It should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 × 4 mm, and arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen
    • Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained

 

 

  • Classification: SILLENCE classification
  • Treatment: 
    • Bisphosphonates to decrease osteoclastic bone resorption
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIAI or COLIA2 gene.
       
  • SOFIELD MILLER surgery (SEEKH KEBAB surgery)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia. It is a primary defect of endochondral bone formation. Autosomal dominant but 80% are spontaneous mutations. It is the effect of excessive growth hormone on the mature skeleton. Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation. It is most common form of disproportionate dwarfism. Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia is most severe in proximal limbs. Trunk height is be normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished. Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition. The patients have normal intelligence, trident hand (separation between middle and ring fingers) and starfish hand (middle finger shorter). The vertebrae shows short interpedicular distance, bullet shape. The pelvis appears like a champagne glass (pelvic width > depth). Hooked vertebra are seen.

 

 

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome. It is the Fibrillin 1 defect. There is a disproportionate increase in the height. The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider-like appearance). Scoliosis, Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum, Hyperlaxity, High-arched palate, Pes planus, and Hammer toes are seen. Early OA is a feature. Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Cretinism. Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism). Congenital hypothyroidism can be endemic, genetic, or sporadic. Sporadic and genetic cretinism results from abnormal development, or function of the foetal thyroid gland. Cretinism has been almost completely eliminated in developed countries by early diagnosis by newborn screening schemes and iodine supplementation programs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent breaking of long bones in children is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

 

Explanation:

 

The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.

 

 

Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ

 

IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop, which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst. It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.

 

Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below.(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colour Doppler

 

This technology uses standard ultrasound methods to produce an image of structures and also captures Doppler data to visualize moving blood cells. The color (usually red or blue) in the image represents the speed and direction of blood flow, relative to the ultrasound probe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG (Ultrasound): Standard ultrasound uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It's primarily used to view organs and structures and can also detect abnormalities but does not inherently provide information about blood flow unless it includes Doppler capabilities.

 

Option C. X-ray: An X-ray uses radiation to produce images and cannot display blood flow.

 

Option D. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans use X-rays from multiple angles to create detailed cross-sectional images of the body's internal structures.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In the image provided, the Color Doppler is displaying the blood flow within a specific blood vessel, likely a carotid artery (indicated by R Prox ICA, meaning the proximal right internal carotid artery). The Doppler waveform below the image shows the blood flow velocity during the cardiac cycle, indicating the health and patency of the vessel.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with neck stiffness and severe headache with CT showing blood in the basal cistern suggests towards the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is an extra axial intracranial hemorrhage and denotes the presence of blood within the subarachnoid space. NCCT shows the hyperdense “star of death” appearance.

 

The modified Fisher scale is a grading method for SAH as seen on non-contrast CT (NCCT). The Hunt and Hess scale is used to describe the severity of SAH and to predict survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Meningitis can also present with neck stiffness and headache. NCCT would be normal. CE-MRI shows thickened enhancing meninges.

 

Option C: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage is acute accumulation of blood within the parenchyma of the brain and on CT scan a hyperdense collection of blood, often with surrounding hypodense edema.

 

Option D: Hemorrhagic stroke is a broader classification and usually indicated IC bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a critical condition indicated by CT findings of blood in the subarachnoid space, presenting clinically with rapid onset headache and neck stiffness. It requires immediate medical attention and further evaluation with grading scales like the modified Fisher scale to assess severity and guide treatment.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neer classification grade 4

 

IMPORTANT CLASSIFICATIONS OF VARIOUS FRACTURES

 

 

NEER CLASSIFICATION OF PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • The classification consists of four major groupings, based on the number of displaced parts.
  • One-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 1 to 4 parts
    • No or minimal displacement (i.e. <1 cm and <45°)
    • Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures and are almost always treated conservatively.

 

 

  • Two-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 2 to 4 parts
    • One part is displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • Four possible types of two-part fractures are: 
      1. Surgical neck: most common
      2. Greater tuberosity
        • Frequently seen in anterior shoulder dislocation
        • A lower threshold of displacement (>5 mm)
      3. Anatomical neck
      4. Lesser tuberosity: uncommon
    • These fractures account for approximately 20% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Three-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts
