    • Two parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • 2 three-part fracture patterns are encountered:
      1. Greater tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the lesser tuberosity and articular surface which remain together – most common pattern
      2. Lesser tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the greater tuberosity and articular surface which remain together
    • These fractures account for approximately 5% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Four-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves all 4 parts
    • Three parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°) with respect to the 4th.
    • These fractures are uncommon (<1% of proximal humeral fractures).
    • This pattern has poor non-operative results as the articular surface is no longer attached to any parts of the humerus. This pattern has a high incidence of osteonecrosis. These fractures require operative management.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4. This system is used to classify the scapular fractures.

 

 

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3. The Garden classification of subcapital femoral neck fractures is the most widely used. It predicts the development of osteonecrosis.

 

 

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5. This is used to classify tibial plateau fracture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the grade 4 of the Neer’s classification of the proximal humerus fracture where all the fractured parts of the humerus are displaced.

questions.text:
True statements in view of septic arthritis are:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Widening of joint space is there.
  2. Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate.
  3. Incision and drainage is frequently required.
  4. Kocher criteria used to differentiate from transient synovitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All are correct

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then Arthritis (joint destruction) develops.
  • Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and Pathology: The hematogenous route of infection is the most common route in all age groups.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Staph. aureus is the most common organism in neonates.
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis till proved otherwise.

 

 

  • Diagnosis: 
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swellings.
    • The earliest plain film radiographic findings of septic arthritis are soft tissue swelling around the joint and a widened joint space from joint effusion; however, uniform narrowing of the joint has also been described.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint will help to confirm the diagnosis by culture and sensitivity and can also help to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Aspiration also decreases intra-articular pressure and reduces chances of avascular necrosis (AVN) of femoral head.
    • Aspiration shows > 50,000 cells/mL and >75% polymorphoneutrophils in septic arthritis.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
    • Kocher Criterion:
      • To differentiate between septic arthritis and transient synovitis, the predictive value of four original Kocher criteria (fever, inability to bear weight, elevated serum white blood cell count, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate) must be present.
      • Non-weight-bearing on affected side
      • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate > 40
      • Fever > 38.5°C
      • White blood cell count >12,000
  • Septic Arthritis with Negative Cultures – Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and Associates Criterion):

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment options include:
      • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule)
      • Surgical drainage (decompression)
      • Synovectomy
      • Antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral)
    • Duration of antibiotics is same as osteomyelitis as usually focus is from the bone.
    • If signs of local sepsis do not abate and synovial fluid analysis does not move to normal within 2 days after treatment, open surgical drainage is indicated.
    • If the purulent fluid becomes too thick to aspirate, open surgical drainage is indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given statements in the question are all correct about the septic arthritis.

 

  • There is widening of joint space.
  • Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate.
  • Incision and drainage is frequently required to treat the infection.
  • Kocher criteria is used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis.

questions.text: What is the substance used in PET scan? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Fluoro-deoxy-glucose

 

This is a glucose analog where fluorine-18 replaces a normal hydroxyl group. FDG is taken up by cells, but unlike glucose, it is not metabolized, making it useful for imaging active tissues like cancer cells which metabolize glucose at high rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tc99m pertechnetate: This is a radioactive form of technetium used primarily in the imaging of the thyroid gland and in nuclear medicine scans like the Meckel’s diverticulum scans. It is not used in PET scans.

 

Option C. Iodine-123: This isotope is primarily used in gamma imaging, particularly in thyroid studies, not in PET scanning.

 

Option D. Tc99-M: This refers to Technetium-99m, used widely in SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) imaging, not in PET scans.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Fluoro-deoxy-glucose (FDG) is the primary tracer used in PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans to image metabolic activity of tissues.

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

 

For injuries like the one shown in the X-ray (fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal), the typical treatment involves immobilization using a plaster of Paris (POP) cast. Foot injuries, including fractures of the metatarsal bones, usually require a period of 6-8 weeks to allow for proper healing. This timeframe is standard for most metatarsal fractures, ensuring that the bone has adequate time to heal and regain strength. Specifically, fractures like the Jones fracture (involving the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction) or the Pseudojones fracture (avulsion fracture) are commonly immobilized for this duration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.

questions.text: Indications for surgery (including biopsy) in a patient with Potts spine are all except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold abscess without neurological involvement

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Imaging:

 

1. Plain radiograph:

 

  • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
  • Reduction of disc space
  • Vertebral body destruction
  • Paravertebral abscess
  • Widening of mediastinum

 

2. CT scan:

 

  • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.

 

3. MRI:

 

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

4. Biopsy:

 

  • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist then, surgery needs to be done.
       
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9–12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18–24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months–1 year).|
       
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
    4. Paravertebral abscess
    5. Spine instability due to kyphotic deformity (kyphotic angles 50-60° or more which is likely to progress)
    6. Pott’s spine resistant to current anti-tuberculosis drugs
    7. To prevent/treat complications like late-onset paraplegia
       
  • Surgical options for most of the cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
  • Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of cold abscess without any neurological involvement is not an indication for biopsy or surgical treatment of Pott’s spine.
  • Neurological involvement which is deteriorating with time is an important indication for surgical intervention.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Abscess

 

The provided MRI images show a ring-enhancing lesion with bright white areas on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), which indicates diffusion restriction. Diffusion restriction on DWI is characteristic of a brain abscess. Brain abscesses typically appear as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction due to the presence of pus, which restricts the movement of water molecules. The absence of bony structures and clear visualization of the brain on the MRI sequence also confirm that this is a DWI image, where bright areas represent restricted diffusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculomas: Tuberculomas often present as multiple ring-enhancing lesions that may conglomerate, and do not show the same characteristic diffusion restriction seen in abscesses. They have a different imaging pattern and usually do not exhibit a single, well-defined ring-enhancing lesion with prominent diffusion restriction.

 

Option C. Cryptococcomas: These lesions are commonly found in the basal ganglia and have a soap-bubble appearance rather than a ring enhancement. Cryptococcomas are typically not associated with the intense diffusion restriction seen in abscesses.

 

Option D. NCC (Neurocysticercosis): NCC lesions often have a characteristic central scolex, which is not visible in this image. The presence of a scolex is a key feature for diagnosing NCC, and the absence of this finding makes NCC less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain abscesses present as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), appearing bright white on DWI due to restricted water movement caused by pus accumulation.

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

Plethoric lung fields are indicative of increased pulmonary arterial blood flow and are seen in:

 

  • Left to right shunts
  • TAPVC
  • TGA
  • Persistent truncus arteriosus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tricuspid atresia does not have plethoric lung fields because in this condition right atrium is atretic.

 

Option C. Ebstein’s anomaly has atrialisation of RV, leading to small outflow tract, and resultant reduced pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option D. TOF has oligemia due to infundibular pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TAPVC is characterized by plethoric lung fields due to the excessive flow of oxygenated blood returning to the right side of the heart and flowing back into the lungs instead of going to the systemic circulation, leading to increased pulmonary pressure and congestion. This condition is a serious congenital heart defect that typically requires corrective surgery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thomas test

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allis test. The Galeazzi test, also called Allis test, is used to assess hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) and can also be used to assess significant leg length inequality. The examination is performed with the child lying supine and their hips flexed to 45 degrees with knees flexed to 90 degrees, and feet on examining table. In this position, look for symmetry in the level of the knees. Galeazzi’s test is positive if the height of the knees is asymmetrical, and may be due to hip dislocation, DDH, congenital femoral shortening, fracture, other congenital conditions. It is also helpful in determining whether the leg length inequality is primarily from the femur or the tibia and can be used to assess leg length with knee or hip flexion contracture.

 

 

Option C. Ober test. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The patient should be in side-lying with the affected side up. Bottom knee and hip should be flexed to flatten the lumbar curve. Stand behind the patient and firmly stabilize the pelvis/greater trochanter to prevent movement in any direction. Grasp the distal end of the patient’s affected leg with your other hand and flex the leg to a right angle at the knee. Extend and abduct the hip joint. Slowly lower the leg towards the table, adduct hip until motion is restricted. Ensure that the hip does not internally rotate and flex during the test and the pelvis must be stabilized. As allowing the thigh to drop in flexion and internal rotation would 'give in' to the tight TFL and not accurately test the length. If the ITB is normal, the leg will adduct with the thigh dropping down slightly below the horizontal, the test is called negative. If the ITB is tight, the leg would remain in the abducted position and the patient would experience lateral knee pain, the test is called positive.

 

 

Option D. Trendelenburg test. The aim of Trendelenburg’s test is to assess the strength of the hip abductors, specifically the gluteus medius and minimus. It is done when a patient complains of a limp, or hip pain or as part of a normal physical examination assessing gait. If the patient is comfortable to stand alone, stand behind the patient. Alternatively, stand in front of the patient, with their forearms positioned on yours to support them. Ask the patient to lift each foot in turn off the ground. When the patient lifts their right foot, the left hip abductors are being tested. When the patient lifts their left foot, the right hip abductors are being tested. Position your hands on the patient’s iliac crests. Observe carefully if the hip on the unsupported side lifts or droops. If the patient is using your arms for support, you will feel them pressing down on one of your arms if their hip abductors are unable to support their weight. A positive Trendelenburg’s sign (pathological) involves sagging of the pelvis on the unsupported side due to the abductor muscles failing to stabilise the hip towards the weight-bearing femur.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thomas test is used to assess the hip flexor contracture.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

 

PATELLA FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • The image displays a displaced patellar fracture, and the treatment of choice is Tension Band Wiring.
  • Tension Band Wiring (TBW) is a surgical method to secure the bones in place which are subjected to tension forces.
  • Wires and Screws or Pins are used to create this tension band effect.
  • In two-part fracture of Patella, the pull of Quadriceps on the proximal fragment keeps them apart.
  • In the operation, first the fractured fragments are reduced, fixed with TBW and then the extensor retinacula are repaired.
  • TBW converts distractive forces into compressive forces.

 

 

  • In case if there is comminuted fracture where accurate reduction is not possible, patellectomy is done.
  • Tension band wiring is done using: 
    • Cancellous screws for fracture of Olecranon process
    • K-wires and stainless steel wires for fracture of Patella

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension band wiring is the gold standard treatment for the two-part patella fracture.

questions.text: Which contrast agent is safe in a patient with renal failure? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG contrast agents

 

Ultrasound (USG) contrast agents, specifically SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are safe to use in patients with renal failure. These microbubbles are filled with gas and are excreted via the lungs rather than the kidneys, making them suitable for patients with compromised renal function. Unlike other contrast agents, USG contrast agents do not rely on renal clearance, thereby avoiding the risk of further renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI contrast agents (Gadolinium-based): These agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, a serious condition affecting the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Iodinated contrast: Commonly used in CT imaging, these agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, which can further impair renal function.

 

Option D. CT contrast agent: Typically, iodinated contrast is used in CT imaging, which is not safe for patients with renal failure for the reasons mentioned above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

USG contrast agents, such as SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are the only contrast agents safe for use in patients with renal failure as they are excreted via the lungs and do not rely on renal clearance.

questions.text: Which type of amputation is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Below knee amputation

 

The image shows an amputation where both the tibia and fibula are visible below the knee, which indicates a below-knee amputation. A dissected specimen of the tibia and fibula below the knee was shown, which matches the image provided. Below-knee amputations involve removing the lower limb while preserving the knee joint, improving the potential for prosthetic use and mobility in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Above knee amputation: This amputation occurs above the knee joint, where the entire knee and part of the femur are removed. However, the image does not show the knee joint being amputated.

 

Option C. Chopart’s amputation: This type of amputation occurs in the intertarsal region of the foot, which is not applicable in this image, as the amputation is clearly higher up, below the knee.

 

Option D. Lisfranc amputation: This refers to an amputation at the tarsometatarsal joint, which is also a lower limb amputation but located in the foot. The image shows an amputation above the foot, making this option incorrect.

 

Different types of amputations:

 

  1. Hip disarticulation: Removal at the hip joint (disarticulation from the joint).
  2. Above knee amputation: Removal above the knee.
  3. Knee disarticulation: Amputation through the knee joint.
  4. Below knee amputation: Removal below the knee.
  5. Syme's amputation: Amputation above the ankle.
  6. Boyd's or Pirogov amputation: Involves cutting the calcaneum (heel bone).
  7. Chopart's amputation: Involves the intertarsal area (just above the calcaneum).
  8. Lisfranc's amputation: Involves the tarsometatarsal joint (between the tarsal and metatarsal bones).
  9. Transmetatarsal amputation: Amputation in between the metatarsal bones.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A below-knee amputation involves the removal of the lower limb below the knee joint, preserving the knee, tibia, and fibula, which improves mobility and function compared to an above-knee amputation.

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray shown below. Identify the likely cause:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital

 

Explanation:

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)

 

CONGENITAL SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Congenital scoliosis is the most frequent congenital deformity of the spine.
  • Congenital curvatures are due to anomalous development of the vertebrae (failure of formation and/or segmentation).
  • In most cases, congenital scolioses are non-hereditary.
  • It is believed to be related to an insult to the fetus during spine embryological development (between the 5th-8th week of gestation).
  • 25% of curves are non-progressive, 25% mildly progressive and 50% highly progressive and will require treatment.
  • The mainstay of treatment is either observation or surgery.
  • The rigidity of the curve is assessed, and the rib hump measured.
  • Associated malformations must be looked for clinically: look for foot or leg asymmetry, craniofacial malformation, a Klippel-Feil web neck, and cardiac and urinary malformations.
  • Full-body-width Postero-anterior (PA) and lateral X-rays are essential.
  • After 1 year of age, X-rays should be taken standing, with the legs in extension and the pelvis level, to compensate for any leg length discrepancy.
  • The Cobb angle will be measured.
  • CT scans shows a bony bar.
  • Congenital scoliosis can be classified into defect of formation or defect of segmentation:
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra (two growth plates) with a contralateral bar
    • Unilateral unsegmented bar
    • Two consecutives fully segmented hemivertebrae
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra
    • Semi segmented hemivertebra
    • Wedge vertebra (partial failure of formation)
    • Incarcerated hemivertebra (smaller and induce little deformity as the hemivertebra sits in a non-growing block; the alignment of the pedicles usually remains straight)

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment consists of either observation of the curve or surgery, or, rarely, bracing.
    • Observation should be applied only for non-progressive curves with a balanced spine.
    • Bracing is inefficient in congenital scoliosis. It may be indicated for long flexible curves or to control the compensatory lumbar curve or help rebalancing the spine, or it may be used after an operation, for instance, until the fusion is solid.
    • Surgery is the mainstay of care.
    • Prophylactic surgery:  surgery that will prevent further worsening or allow progressive correction over time. These operations are in situ fusion and hemi epiphysiodesis.
    • In situ fusion can be done with a single posterior fusion, with or without instrumentation or with an anterior fusion, or a 360° fusion.

 

 

  • Hemiepiphysiodesis tends to achieve progressive correction over time, taking advantage of the intact growth plates on the concave side of the deformity.  It has to be done ideally before the age of 5 to take advantage of the growth potential of the spine to allow a progressive correction of the deformity. It should not be carried out if there is a kyphosis component to the deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic. Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial. It is grouped by age. In children age 3 and younger, it is called infantile scoliosis. In age 4-10, it is called juvenile scoliosis. In age >10, it is called adolescent scoliosis. Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending (Adams test) as opposed to postural scoliosis. Compensatory curve due to limb length discrepancy or sciatic list (due to disc prolapsed) disappear on sitting.  Postural scoliosis disappears on forward bending.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular. This type is caused by a nervous system problem such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and polio. It may present at any age; and in many cases progresses relentlessly, particularly in patients with more severe neurologic and systemic involvement. Progressive deformity may limit mobility and seating status, and may be associated with primary or secondary effects on cardiopulmonary function over time. Management includes observation, non-operative interventions such as bracing, specialized seating systems, and surgery.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis. It is hereditary, hamartomatous disorder, that affects central and peripheral nervous system, skeletal, skin and deeper soft tissue. It is one of the commonest single gene disorder affecting the skeletal system. Clinical presentation includes-cafe au lait spots (most common feature) axillary, and inguinal freckling (2nd m.c), cutaneous neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas (~5% are premalignant), Lisch nodule on iris, veruccous hyperplasia (thickened overgrown valvety soft skin), elephantiasis (pachy- dermatocele), optic glioma, skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, hemihypertrophy) and cognitive deficits (learning disability).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows hemivertebra and block vertebra, which are characteristic of congenital type of scoliosis.

questions.text: The normal Doppler waveform of the venous blood flow is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Monophasic

 

Explanation:

 

The normal Doppler waveform for venous blood flow is monophasic. This refers to the uniform, steady, and continuous flow pattern typically observed in veins, unlike the varying phases seen in arterial blood flow. Monophasic waveforms indicate a lack of cardiac modulation and resistance, which is characteristic of venous structures that carry blood under lower pressure and with less force than arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biphasic: Generally observed in visceral arteries, biphasic waveforms show two distinct directional phases in the blood flow, reflecting the resistance encountered by the blood as it moves through these arteries.

 

 

Option C. Triphasic: This waveform is characteristic of extremity arteries and includes three phases—forward flow, brief reverse flow, and forward flow again, which correspond to the cardiac cycle's effects on arterial blood movement.

 

 

Option D. Absent flow: This is not a normal finding and indicates a blockage or absence of blood flow, which requires further investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doppler waveforms refer to the morphology of pulsatile blood flow velocity tracings on spectral Doppler ultrasound. 

 

In Doppler ultrasound, the normal venous waveform is monophasic, indicating a steady flow without the complex fluctuations seen in arterial blood flow.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurocysticercosis

 

Explanation:

 

The MRI brain image shows multiple cyst-like lesions within the brain, which are characteristic of neurocysticercosis, often described as a "starry sky" appearance. Neurocysticercosis is an infection caused by the larvae of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium. These lesions are typically cystic with a scolex (head of the larva) visible within the cysts, which is a diagnostic feature. This condition is common in areas where pork is commonly consumed and sanitation practices are poor, and it can lead to serious neurological symptoms like the ones presented by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculoma: Generally appears as well-defined, enhancing masses on MRI, which are not specifically indicated by the cystic nature of the lesions seen in this image.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Common in HIV patients, but typically presents as multiple ring-enhancing lesions rather than the cystic lesions with a clear scolex seen here.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Typically appear as gelatinous masses in the brain and would not usually present with the clear, cystic appearance with scoleces indicative of parasitic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis should be considered in patients presenting with multiple cystic brain lesions, especially in contexts of headache and altered mental status, where the history and radiological findings suggest the presence of cysts with scoleces typical of tapeworm larvae.

questions.text: What is the management of choice for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coiling

 

The management of choice for aneurysms by interventional radiologists is coiling. This minimally invasive procedure involves the insertion of platinum coils into the aneurysm through an endovascular route. The coils promote clotting within the aneurysm, effectively reducing the risk of rupture and stabilizing the aneurysm.

 

Coiling is performed under the guidance of digital subtraction angiography (DSA), which allows the radiologist to visualize the blood vessels and accurately place the coils within the aneurysm. This technique has become the gold standard for treating cerebral aneurysms due to its minimally invasive nature and high success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clipping: This is a surgical procedure where a neurosurgeon places a clip at the neck of the aneurysm to prevent blood flow into it. While effective, it is more invasive than coiling and typically not performed by interventional radiologists.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). It is not a treatment for aneurysms but a supportive therapy to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Angioplasty: Angioplasty is used to widen narrowed or obstructed blood vessels, often in cases of peripheral arterial disease. It is not a primary treatment for aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coiling is the preferred management for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists, involving the insertion of coils to promote clotting and stabilize the aneurysm.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with multiple injuries, which included a femur fracture as well. He developed confusion, dyspnea, and a rash over his body. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fat embolism

 

  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

  • The diagnosis is considered usually after 48 hours. 

 

Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours think of it!

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. 

  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).

    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:

      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea

      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation

      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder

 

  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:

    • Fracture stabilization

    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:

      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)

      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)

  • Offset its effect by:

    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)

    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release

    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.

  • Treatment:

    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.

    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.

    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

     

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism. An air embolism occurs when air is admitted into the vascular system. It can occur iatrogenically via interventional procedures but has also been described as a complication from a blunt and penetrating trauma. The most important diagnostic criterion is the patient's history. The procedures that carry the greatest risk of air embolism are craniotomy in the sitting position, cesarean section, hip replacement, and cardiopulmonary bypass. If the patient is conscious, chest pain, dyspnea, headache, and confusion can all be symptoms. If the embolus is severe, cardiac ischemia, arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest can ensue. 

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism. Many PEs are likely undiagnosed. Most PEs originate as venous thromboembolisms (VTEs) in the lower extremities or pelvic veins. Less frequently, upper extremity thromboembolic events lead to PE. Major risk factors for thromboembolic events include recent immobilization, MI, CVA, surgery, and recent trauma. PE may be asymptomatic or present with sudden death. Characteristic signs and symptoms such as tachycardia, dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxemia, and shock are non-specific. 

 

Option D. DIC. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a hypercoagulable state that can lead to both microvascular and macrovascular clotting and compromised blood flow, ultimately resulting in multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. It typically occurs as an acute complication in patients with underlying life-threatening illnesses such as severe sepsis, hematologic malignancies, severe trauma, or placental abruption. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with fracture of femur, complaint of breathlessness after 48 hours, is highly suggestive of fat embolism.
